title: RL34130
content: The 2008 farm bill expanded on renewable energy policies established in the 2002 farm bill, which was the first to include an energy title. This title authorized funding for research on agriculture-based renewable energy and promoted the adoption of renewable energy systems. Interest in renewable energy has since increased due to rising petroleum prices. The 2008 farm bill expanded on renewable energy policies established in the 2002 farm bill, which authorized grants, loans, and loan guarantees for research on agriculture-based renewable energy. Interest in renewable energy has grown rapidly due to rising petroleum prices and increased biofuels production. Ethanol and biodiesel receive significant federal support. The 2008 farm bill reflects the increased role of biofuels in response to rising international petroleum prices and domestic biofuels production. Ethanol and biodiesel receive federal support through tax incentives, loans, grants, and regulatory programs. The 2008 farm bill reflects the increased role of biofuels with federal support in the form of tax incentives, loans, and grants. It aligns with the Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007, emphasizing the production of biofuels from cellulosic feedstocks to meet the expanded renewable fuels standard. EISA sets a goal of 36 billion gallons of renewable fuels by 2022, including biodiesel and cellulosic ethanol. The Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007 (EISA) expanded the Renewable Fuels Standard (RFS) to 36 billion gallons by 2022, with specific targets for biodiesel and cellulosic ethanol production. This shift towards cellulosic ethanol is driven by concerns over economic and environmental issues associated with corn starch-based ethanol. The Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007 set targets for renewable fuels, including an implicit cap on corn starch ethanol. Concerns over economic and environmental issues have led to a shift towards cellulosic ethanol production. Ethanol production using a significant portion of U.S. corn has impacted commodity prices and food inflation. The increase in ethanol production using U.S. corn has led to higher corn prices due to competition with petroleum. This has sparked the "food versus fuel" debate, especially during the 2008 farm bill discussions, as food prices rose globally. The 2008 farm bill debate intensified the "food versus fuel" discussion as ethanol production using U.S. corn drove up prices. Ethanol's profitability is linked to petroleum and corn prices, with rising petroleum prices increasing demand for ethanol and corn. Federal programs supporting renewable energy production are not under the U.S. Department of Agriculture's jurisdiction. The federal programs supporting renewable energy production, including the mandate for biofuels in the national fuel supply, originated outside of the U.S. Department of Agriculture's jurisdiction. The Renewable Fuel Standard (RFS) and federal tax credits for biofuel blenders have legislative origins outside of the farm bill, such as the Energy Policy Act of 2005 and the American Jobs Creation Act of 2004. The 2008 farm bill significantly expands programs to support biofuels. The tax credits for biofuel blenders were initially in the American Jobs Creation Act of 2004 and extended in the Tax Relief Act of 2010. The 2008 farm bill expanded programs to support biofuels, including corn starch-based ethanol, cellulosic ethanol, and biodiesel. The 2008 farm bill, similar to the 2002 farm bill, includes an energy title (Title IX) focusing on biofuels production. It covers various energy and agricultural topics, with provisions for corn starch-based ethanol, cellulosic ethanol, and biodiesel. Research provisions are in Title VII, while tax and trade provisions are in Title XV. Title IX in the 2008 farm bill replaces the structure of the 2002 farm bill's Title IX, with 13 new provisions in section 9001. Key provisions include a new cellulosic ethanol production tax credit, promotion of cellulosic feedstocks production, marketing infrastructure, refinery development, grants and loan guarantees for biofuels research and production. The 2008 farm bill introduces provisions for promoting cellulosic ethanol production, incentivizing biofuels research and production, studying market and environmental impacts of biofuels, expanding federal procurement of bio-based products, and supporting rural energy. The 2008 farm bill energy title provides financial incentives and support for the production of advanced biofuels, mainly cellulosic, through programs like BCAP and the Biorefinery Assistance program. The 2008 farm bill energy title supports the production of advanced biofuels through programs like BCAP and the Biorefinery Assistance program, providing incentives for feedstock production and refinery construction. Cellulosic ethanol is produced from cellulose, hemicellulose, or lignin derived from plant material. The Sun Grant Program and other initiatives support advanced biofuels research using various feedstocks like cellulose, hemicellulose, and lignin from plants. Cellulosic ethanol can be produced from agricultural products such as prairie grasses, fast-growing woody crops, and waste biomass materials. Cellulosic feedstock like prairie grasses and fast-growing woody crops offer long-term supply potential for producing ethanol. These materials thrive on marginal lands, require little water or fertilizer, and can be sourced from waste biomass materials. Cellulosic ethanol, derived from sources like prairie grasses and agricultural residues, offers environmental benefits over corn-based ethanol. Title XV of the 2008 farm bill extends and modifies tax credits and tariffs on ethanol to promote cellulosic ethanol production. The 2008 farm bill extends tax credits and tariffs on ethanol to promote cellulosic ethanol production. A producer tax credit of $1.01 per gallon applies to ethanol produced from cellulosic feedstocks, while the ethanol blender tax credit was reduced to $0.45 per gallon in 2009. The ethanol import tariff of $0.54 per gallon was extended to 2010. Ethanol proponents argue that the tariff benefits the U.S. ethanol industry. The blender tax credit for ethanol was reduced from $0.51 to $0.45 per gallon in January 2009. The ethanol import tariff of $0.54 per gallon was extended to the end of 2010. The tariff benefits the U.S. ethanol industry by protecting it from lower-cost imports and offsets the blender tax credit. The U.S. ethanol industry benefits from a tariff protecting it from cheaper imports and offsetting the blender tax credit. The Tax Relief, Unemployment Insurance Reauthorization, and Job Creation Act of 2010 extended both the ethanol blender tax credit and import tariff until the end of 2011 at $0.45 per gallon and $0.54 per gallon, respectively. The tariff exceeds the blender tax credit by nine cents, imposing a punitive duty on imported ethanol.
